pages.text: MIDI Sequencers can create, edit, save, and play sequences of MIDI messages that are aligned to a temp to form a song.$(br2)Generally MIDI sequences are saved to a file with a .mid extension. Many songs have been translated into MIDI format and can found online via Google by searching for "<Song Name> MIDI".

pages.title: Uses
pages.text: MIDI files are not as popular as they once were, but they are still used for multiple things today.$(br2)MIDI files are commonly used for Karaoke, some video game music, music tutorials, and pre-recorded songs on digital instruments among other things.

pages.title: Format
pages.text: MIDI sequences store $(l:midi_messages)MIDI messages$(/l) on a timeline and typically can store data for all 16 $(l:midi_channels)MIDI channels$(/l). This allows a single MIDI file to hold all the components of an entire song.$(br2)Each channel that is used will have a $(l:midi_programs)MIDI program$(/l) assigned which maps it to a single instrument. It is possible to have multiple channels assigned to the same program.

pages.title: Format
pages.text: As mentioned in the $(l:midi_channels)MIDI channels$(/l) section channel 10 is reserved for percussion. As a result, when playing an instrument in MIMI using MIDI input it is recommended to disable channel 10 unless you're playing the drum kit.$(br2)When playing MIDI data on an instrument it is recommended to play only a few channels per instrument at one time.
